utterances: Speaking of financial literacy.
I'll hand you this one as well, and he'll be…
Thank you.
…on his way there before very long.
And let's see if we can get another caller on the line.
And this is Anita, Anita with us from Salt Lake City.
Hi, good afternoon Neal and Leonard.
My name is Anita Watson.
I actually work for the University of Utah through the president's office, a program called University Neighborhood Partners.
Were you right?
Were you correct in your assessment?

Our goal is to work with communities, go to our underserved communities, low-income, highly-populated refugee and immigrated populations, and trying to work with University of Utah departments, colleges who are interested in investing into the community and tapping into community agents who are already services within the community.

And together with the partnership, reaching out to those communities and learning, you know, from the communities that they are also an asset to who we are - economically, culturally, diversedly(ph) - and also promoting education.
Of course, we'd love all of our students in Utah to consider the University of Utah.
But if we can get any child into higher education; any parent, more knowledge on how they can support their children achieve his goal, we're really educating families.
And I think that is most importantly.
Again, it's an incredible program - University Neighborhood Partners.
I've had the pleasure of working now for three years in training parents on how to support their children through education.
From early childhood development all the way through higher education, vocational training - trade school, however we can get our young people more educated and into economic and financial freedom…
And is there…
…some opportunities.
And is there evidence that this program is working?
Oh, absolutely.
We've - that's a big component of what we do with research.
University of Utah is a research school, so we document all of our interactions with families.

We have relationships with, not only community agencies, but with property owners, with apartment caucuses to see our agency as one who wants to work with the community to help the residents, help tenants, to be financially fit, have life skills.
We work with Head Start, another early childhood program.
We work with your the local folks for these school districts.
This is something that we will continue forward.
It's only growing because our, you know, our stories are getting out there and we have many, many residents who've hacked into how they can really seek education as freedom.
And myself, I'm 30-year-old single mother of two children.
I was a teenage mother.
I am a nontraditional student of the University of Utah.
And it's been an amazing experience.
Mm-hmm.
Well, Anita, thanks very much and continued good luck with the program.
Thank you very much, Neal.
(Unintelligible).
Appreciate it.
As you hear about these programs, certainly, educating parents to, you know, foster education, these goes to the heart of something, but this sounds like a very diffused program.
This last program, yeah.
But I think that, you know, that it maybe necessary for the programs to be diffused, because again, I don't think the problems that we're dealing with are all tied up in just the child life.
There are all the elements around the child.
There's the community and the family when the child is growing up.
A lot of those aren't really healthy for the child's development either.
So, you know, again I keep coming back to the Harlem children's own model, which is that, you know, we need to fix it all.
Mm-hmm.
There's a holistic approach…
Yeah, very, very much a holistic approach.
We're talking with syndicated columnist Leonard Pitts about his series ""What Works?"" And you're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And as this series goes on, it's an occasional series, you're going to go visit these places, check them out and see how they're going.
Is there going to be another level of frustration when you identify things that do work and wonder why they can't expand into other towns and other cities?
I think that that's probably going to be the next level for the column.
I think probably sometime next year there'll be a primal scream column that says, look, we know what works, you know, so now let's do it.
And I'll, you know, I'll probably start screaming at whoever's in office at that time because it's just - there's no reason that this should not be.
I think part of the problem is that we have come to look at these issues as, as you said, intractable.
And I think that we've - one the things of that we are missing in this country is a sense of the possible.

And the example that I used - and will probably use when I write the column -is the Civil Rights Movement, which dealt with issues that were intractable, things that, you know, customs and laws of segregation and discrimination that had been in place for a century or more and changed them - changed the complete, you know, texture of American life in 10 years.
Just - I mean, in historical terms, overnight - changed the world.
And if that can happen once it seems to me that it can happen again.
But I think that part of the problem is we need to be very careful about what we define as intractable or something that I can't - that cannot be changed.
Thus has it always been the shall it ever be - says who?
Says who?
At the same time, and while you're pursuing these solutions, you also note in your column that you're not going to stop writing about problems either.
No.
No. I think some people may have mistaken me for that.
No. I mean, I will be dealing with problems and with issues and with things that just strike as wrong.
But a greater focus of the column, at least, in so far as the problems of African-American children of an issue will be what can we do to fix.
Let's see if we can get one more caller in.
This is - I can't even read this, Hiawatha(ph).
Hiawatha with us from Oklahoma City.
(Caller): Yes.
Hi.
How are you doing?
Okay.
Good.
Yeah.
I happen to be driving up the highway on my way to the Indian health clinic to drop off a letter for a grant for a community center.
I'm a preventionist(ph) here in Oklahoma City.
I work with the entire county, so I work with everyone from African-Americans, Native Americans, Hispanics, even affluent kids dealing with alcohol, tobacco and other drugs.
But one thing that touched me - I grew up in Chicago, inner city - I did have that mentor, we did have surroundings - but we also had resources in our community.
And I heard that Leonard had mentioned about programs being a bad word - research based.
I think the dominant culture determines this research base.
We didn't have research base when I was 16, but I had relationships.
We had cultural competencies in our schools.
People were concerned about the kids.
We had expectations throughout the entire community that we don't have today.
We had - we've got stereotypical expectations now.
We don't think that our kids can do things, so they don't either.
Mm-hmm.
That expectations heard of Leonard Pitts, well, Wilton Harris talked about that too.
You know, I've written about it as well.
I think that a kid will tend to rise up to or down to whatever expectations he or she…
Whatever you set.
…perceived as being set.
It's about more than what you say you expect.
It's about what you show that you expect.
Mm-hmm.
Hopefully.
Hiawatha, thanks very much for the call.
Good luck with the grant.
Alrighty.
Thank you.
So long.
Leonard Pitts, thanks very much for your time.
It's my pleasure.
Thank you for having me.
I hope we can have you back from time to time to check in on how you're doing.
I'll be glad to.
And I'd like to invite our listeners to pick up on his idea.
Tell us what's working in your neck of the woods, be it fighting crime, addiction, even potholes.
E-mail us, talk@npr.org or comment on our blog about what solutions are working in your community.
(Soundbite of music)
What local models are there that could be expanded successfully to other towns and cities across the country?
That's at npr.org/blogofthenation.
We're going to pick this issue up from time to time, and talk with Leonard Pitts again too.

Leonard Pitts Jr. is Pulitzer Prize-winning, nationally syndicated columnist for the Miami Herald and author of ""Becoming Dad: Black Men and the Journey to Fatherhood."" He was kind enough to join us today here in Studio 3A.
